summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan opposing Ghislaine Maxwell's request to use criminal discovery materials in her civil cases. The government argues the protective order prohibits using discovery for civil litigation and that the materials pertain to an ongoing grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and possible co-conspirators.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20 Cr. 330) who is seeking court permission to use criminal discovery materials in unrelated civil litigation.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell to whom this opposition letter is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased financier who is the subject of an ongoing grand jury investigation into his possible co-conspirators.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The Acting U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York who respectfully submits this opposition letter.

connections.description: The document references an ongoing grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his possible co-conspirators, with Maxwell being the defendant in the related criminal case.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case, and this letter is the government's opposition to a motion filed by Maxwell's defense.

events.title: Government Seeks Modification of Protective Orders
events.description: The Government applied ex parte and under seal to relevant courts to request modification of protective orders to permit compliance with grand jury subpoenas issued in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Court-1 Grants Government's Application
events.description: One court (referred to as Court-1) granted the Government's application, permitting the Government to share its order—which prohibited further dissemination—with the Recipient of the subpoenas.

events.title: Defense Letter Filed
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team filed a letter requesting permission to use criminal discovery materials in certain civil cases.

events.title: Government Files Opposition Letter
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office files this letter in opposition to Maxwell's August 17 request, arguing it violates the protective order and jeopardizes an ongoing investigation.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The government has produced over 165,000 pages of discovery to Ghislaine Maxwell's defense in her criminal case.
An ongoing grand jury investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his possible co-conspirators remains active, and details are not public.
The government issued grand jury subpoenas to a 'Recipient' in early 2019 and sought court modifications to protective orders to obtain compliance.

The government strongly opposes Maxwell's attempt to use criminal discovery materials in her civil cases, arguing it violates the protective order and could reveal details of the ongoing investigation.
Two courts (referred to as Court-1 and Court-2) have kept filings regarding the grand jury subpoenas under seal, with limited exceptions for discovery in Maxwell's criminal case.
